title: Redis scan

content:
Do you often encounter a shortage of letters when writing papers? The arbitrary use of letters earlier on can lead to conflicts when defining new variables later, and changing already defined letters can result in inevitable tedious modifications.
Have you ever read papers where undefined letters appear and often affect understanding? It often requires repeatedly searching and wasting a lot of time, and more importantly, you may not necessarily find them.
To solve the above two problems, I have compiled a list of common letter usages in the field of computer science and mathematics (case insensitive), and this table will be updated periodically.
A: action
B: borel base,batch
C: constant, channel
D: data, degree, distance (metric), dimension
E: edge, element, expectation
F: filter, function, face
G: graph, function
H: Hilbert, function, height, Hessian
I: dumb index, identifier, imaginary_unit
J: dumb index
K: key, dumb index, constant
L: length, operator
M: matrix, measure
N: positive_integer, total_number
O: order
P: permutationï¼Œprobability
Q: query, rational_numerï¼Œprobability
R: real, reward
S: sample, set, state
T: time, topology, transform, temperature
U: variable, open set, domain
V: variable, open set, range, vertex
W: variable, width, weight
X: input, unknown_number, variate
Y: output, unknown_number, variate
Z: unknown_number, variate, integer
$\alpha$: constant
$\beta$: coefficient for EMA, costant
$\chi$: Chi-squared distribution, statistics, constant,
$\delta$: delta function, $\epsilon$-$\delta$ language
$\epsilon$: $\epsilon$-$\delta$ language
$\varepsilon$: $\epsilon$-$\delta$ language
$\phi$: function
$\gamma$: function, constant
$\eta$: learning_rate $\iota$: including_map
$\kappa$: constant, $\kappa$-coefficient
$\lambda$: eigenvalue, laplacian_factor
$\mu$: measure, distribution, mean
$\nu$: photon, constant
$\omicron$:infinitesimal
$\pi$: policy, distribution, measure
$\theta$: parameter
$\rho$: density
$\sigma$: sum, standard_deviation, variation
$\tau$: permutation, stopping time
$\upsilon$: displacement, constant
$\omega$: order, domain, open set
$\xi$: variate
$\psi$: function
$\zeta$: variate
For the first issue, when writing a paper and needing to define a new letter but without a particularly good choice, select letters whose common usage ï¼ˆlisted aboveï¼‰ do definitely not appear your paper for use.
For the second issue, when encountering undefined letters, directly check the above list to see if some common usage has a reasonable explanation within the paper.
For any republication, please contact me.
summary: Do you often encounter a shortage of letters when writing papers? The arbitrary use of letters earlier on can lead to conflicts when defining new variables later, and changing already defined letters can result in inevitable tedious modifications. Have you ever read papers where undefined letters appear and often affect understanding? It often requires repeatedly searching and wasting a lot of time, and more importantly, you may not necessarily find them. To solve the above two problems, I have compiled a list of common letter usages in the field of computer science and mathematics (case insensitive), and this table will be updated periodically. A: action B: borel base,batch C: constant, channel D: data, degree, distance (metric), dimension E: edge, element, expectation F: filter, function, face G: graph, function H: Hilbert, function, height, Hessian I: dumb index, identifier, imaginary_unit J: dumb
title: Running out of letters? Unclear meanings in papers?
